The following link is an insite to the view point of an Iraqi who was imprisioned by Saddam and yet still opposes the US occupation of Iraq. I found it to be a very good read and only wish it was longer.
 
 
 http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/239DF360-3640-457C-BA99-5FD497547598.htm

It is nice to hear insight from some one like that, who knows all sides of this issue.
 
 I think this stuck out from that article and explains a lot (especially with regards to "global leadership"):
 
 
The claim that oil was the motivation for the war on Iraq has been controversial. Do you think oil had anything to do with it?
 
 The US is importing 55-60% of its oil needs, and the percentage is expected to reach 70% in 10 years. That means the US needs oil for its own use and as an economic card.
 
 We should not forget that Europe does not follow the US as many think. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Europe is no longer in need of the US, and the US realises that.
 
 In the eastern hemisphere we have China whose GDP (gross domestic product) is expected to overtake America's in the future.
 
 Knowing that Europe and other big players are trying to book a place for themselves in tomorrow's world, the US is interested in disrupting oil flow to such huge competitive blocs.
 
 I think it is vital for any power to control the world's most important resource - oil.

 
 XXXXXXit, that explains everything. 
 
 .

Why didn't you cite the hundreds of thousands who praise us? Because it doesn't fit your story. There is always going to be somebody who is against any issue. And if you think pointing out 1 person who opposed our invasion of Iraq proves a point, you're absolutely wrong.
he gave one, you gave none. I'd say he has the advantage.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Of homeland, identity and occupation
